text: Smart Retail Traders, Short Sellers, and Stock Returns Ekkehart Boehmer and Wanshan Song October 23, 2020 Abstract Using short sell transactions data from 2010 to 2016, this paper is the first to provide a comprehensive sample of short selling initiated by retail investors. We find that retail short selling can predict negative stock returns. A trading strategy that mimics weekly retail shorting earns an annualized risk-adjusted value-(equal-) weighted return of 6% (12.25%). Their predictive power is beyond that coming from retail investors as a group or from off-exchange institutional short sellers. Our results suggest that retail short sellers can profitably exploit public information, especially when it is negative. Retail short sellers also tend to be contrarians who provide liquidity when the market is one-sided due to (institutional) buying pressure. text: In the academic world, short sellers are generally regarded as informed traders who help promote price discovery and supply liquidity. Boehmer, Jones, and Zhang (2008) attribute most of the price discovery that accrues with short selling to institutional traders rather than retail short sellers. Yet, because of data limitations, it is difficult to generate large-sample evidence on this issue. The main role that retail short sellers play remains ambiguous. Earlier literature suggests that retail investors are noise traders who do not contribute to price discovery (Odean, 1998; Barber and Odean, 2000; 2001; 2008), but recent literature disagrees with this view (Kaniel, Saar, and Titman, 2008; Kaniel, Liu, Saar, and Titman, 2012; Kelley and Tetlock, 2013; Barrot, Kaniel, and Sraer, 2016; Boehmer, Jones, Zhang, and Zhang, 2019). Here, we examine whether retail traders‚Äô short selling can account for the information reflected by retail trades. We examine retail short sellers, a new, yet understudied, group of traders. Our sample starts with FINRA TRF transaction-level short-sale data, which must be reported to the public since September 20091. This dataset includes transaction time (in seconds), share price, and number of shares for every off-exchange short sale transaction in an exchange-listed stock, and is a subset of the transactions reported in the daily TAQ (exchange code ‚ÄúD‚Äù). In addition, a review of the order routing disclosures required by Rule 606 of Regulation NMS reveals that nearly all retail orders are routed to off-exchange market makers2 and reported to FINRA TRFs. By combining these two observations, we can identify retail short-selling as a subset of FINRA TRF dataset. text: Boehmer, Jones, Zhang, and Zhang (2019) document that the OTC market makers generally provide retail orders with a small price improvement. Exploiting this observation, they identify retail trades from TAQ data and find that they are quite informed, but the precise nature of retail investors‚Äô information remains unclear. Moreover, the existence and the role of retail short sellers are not clear either. In this paper, we dissect the joint presence of short sellers, retail traders (including retail short sellers) and other over-the-counter trading that we mostly attribute to dark pool trading by exploiting this novel comprehensive short sell transaction level dataset. We also ask which traders‚Äô order flows are related to liquidity provision and which to price discovery. Additionally, we highlight the heterogeneity among retail investors and address the effect of trading platforms and the degree of immediacy that either side of the trade demands. Our results are consistent with the information hypothesis: retail short sellers have and act on unique information beyond that coming from other investors, but they are also consistent with strategic liquidity provision that retail short sellers provide to other traders in one-sided markets. This paper is the first to construct a comprehensive sample and provide evidence of retail short selling. Exploiting short sell transaction data provided by FINRA, we identify marketable retail short sell orders as those short sale orders that experience sub-penny price improvement compared to the national best bid and offer. Our sample is from January 2010 to December 2016 and includes total 5,332 stocks, with an average of 3,532 stocks each day. On average, retail short sellers trade 7,925 shares per stock-day, which is around 10.92% of retail trading, 6.36% of off-exchange short selling, and about 0.78% of total trading volumes. Using a cross- sectional regression, we find that most of the predictive power survives after controlling for firm characteristics, such as firm size, book to market, turnover, volatility, and past returns. The predictive power also remains significant after controlling for the trading activity of other presumably informed traders. Specifically, we control for the order imbalance of retail investors, defined as retail buy volumes minus retail long sell volumes. We also control for other off-exchange short sales, which mostly reflect shorting in dark pools by non-retail traders. The results suggest that retail short sellers are informed traders. But are there any differences between retail investors‚Äô overall trades and their short sales? Retail investors who are able to sell short stocks may be different from the typical retail investors, who do not necessarily have margin accounts that allow short selling (Gamble and Xu, 2017). To address this question, we conduct double sorts. The first sort is on retail trading and the second sort is on retail shorting. This approach provides portfolios that vary in terms of retail shorting activity but hold constant the level of overall (other) retail trading. We find that retail short selling can predict future negative returns in each of the five quintile portfolios, suggesting that retail short sellers have additional information over the information that retail investors have in general. In addition, we use cross-sectional regressions to test whether retail short sellers trade the same particular types of firms as other retail traders do. The results show that retail short sellers can predict returns in all market cap and liquidity groups that we employ. The predictions of retail short sellers are stronger for liquid stocks. In contrast, other (non-short) retail traders can better predict small-cap and illiquid stocks, but they have less predictive power for returns of large-cap and liquid stocks. This is different from the typical retail investors who tend to have an information advantage in small firms. text: How should we interpret the observation that retail short sellers as a group seem to be able to predict stock returns? We consider two alternative explanations about retail shorting and stock prices to shed light on these issues. First, retail short sellers are informed traders who are at least as sophisticated as institutional short sellers. In this view, retail short sellers have access to public information that they can exploit in their trading. They benefit as this information is fully incorporated into stock prices (Christophe, Ferri, and Angel, 2004; Engelberg, Reed, and Ringgenberg, 2012; Boehmer, Jones, Wu, and Zhang, 2020). To test this hypothesis, we select a sample of news related to corporate earnings‚Äô information and analysts‚Äô information. By separating days when there is news from those days when there is no news, we find that retail short sellers‚Äô predictive power for next week‚Äôs return doubles on news days compared to non-news days. Next, we select the days with only negative news announcement, including the days with negative unexpected earnings‚Äô surprises, analyst recommendation downgrades, and negative analyst earnings revision. We find that retail short sellers have greater predictive power on negative news days. Specifically, the prediction of retail short selling on negative news days is -0.074%, which is up to 5 times more informative about the cross-section of next week‚Äôs return compared to other days. The prediction for next month‚Äôs return on negative news days is -0.119%, which doubles compared with other non- negative news days. Put differently, negative news announcements cover around 16.3% of all the underperformance related to retail shorting. We test the differences in information advantage among the group of retail investors. There is no evidence that other retail traders (other than retail short sellers) act on such public information. First, we select quarterly earnings announcements from Compustat and compare the earnings announcements dates from I/B/E/S and Compustat and choose the earlier ones if they are different. Our sample has 5,158 stocks with earnings announcements. Around 1.55% of days have such an announcement. Next, we define the unexpected earnings surprise, UE. The second news category consists of analyst recommendation changes from I/B/E/S. Our sample has 3,570 stocks with analyst recommendation changes. Liquidity Provision Strategies Retail traders can also use short sales to provide liquidity to the impatient who require immediacy. As the buying pressure subsides, prices will revert to the fundamental values and short sellers can cover their positions and potentially earn positive returns. In this scenario, the trading patterns and return predictability are the result of short sellers receiving compensation for providing immediacy (Nagel, 2012). The literature is divided on this point. On one hand, recent studies by Kaniel, Saar, and Titman (2008), Kaniel, Liu, Saar, and Titman (2012), and Barrot, Kaniel, and Sraer (2016) find that retail investors as contrarian individuals can provide liquidity when market liquidity dries up. But none of these studies differentiates retail shorts from other types of retail trading. Retail short selling is different from the typical retail trading in that short sellers will incur costs from foregone interest on collateral and stand risks from recalling shares lent out. On the other hand, Arif, Ben-Rephael, and Lee (2020) show that short sellers frequently provide liquidity. Diether, Lee, and Werner (2009) and Comerton-Forde, Jones, and Putnins (2016) verify that short sellers can provide liquidity to impatient buyers. But most of these samples look at institutional short sells. text: 5.2.2. How Do Retail Short Sells React to Changes in Buying Pressure? It is possible that past and contemporaneous price increases are caused by factors that themselves trigger short selling activity. For example, larger past returns can arise when buying pressure increases during this period. But this effect would be purely liquidity-motivated rather than information-based if retail short sellers just step in to provide liquidity to the impatient buy orders. To better understand this relation, we use three variables that help control for buying pressure at the stock level. The first measure is based on Lee and Ready (1991). We classify trades as either buyer- initiated or seller-initiated, and then calculate order imbalance as: LRoib= (vol_buy- vol_sell)/vol. We construct an additional measure from these imbalances that differentiates between positive and negative imbalances. Following Diether, Lee, and Werner (2009) and Boehmer, Jones, and Zhang (2008), we define this measure as LRoib+, which equals LRoib if LRoib>0 otherwise zero. LRoib+_w includes positive buy-order imbalances in previous week. The second measure is retail net buying. Like above, we calculate the retail order imbalance as (rtlvol_buy-(rtlvol_sell-rtlshort_vol))/vol, and rtloib+ equals rtloib if rtloib>0 and zero otherwise. rtloib+_w includes positive retail buy net buying over the previous week. The third measure is the imbalance based on ‚Äúother‚Äù trades (other than retail), or otheroib+. To construct this measure, we subtract retail trades from overall trades, so this measure also captures institutional trades. Otheroib is calculated as ((vol_buy-rtlvol_buy)- (vol_sell-rtlvol_sell))/vol, and otheroib+ equals otheroib if otheroib>0 and zero otherwise. Otheroib+_w includes positive other buy-order imbalances over the previous week.
